title: R43887
content: The Older Americans Act (OAA), enacted in 1965, provides social services and programs for individuals aged 60 and older. Services include nutrition programs, caregiver support, employment services, and programs to prevent abuse and neglect of older persons. The OAA has seven titles, with most programs administered by the Administration on Aging (AOA). The Older Americans Act (OAA) contains seven titles, with most programs administered by the Administration on Aging (AOA) within the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS). Title V is administered by the Department of Labor's (DOL's) Employment and Training Administration. Funding for OAA Titles II, III, IV, VI, and VII is provided in annual HHS appropriations, while Title V funding is provided in the annual DOL appropriations. The Older Americans Act (OAA) contains seven titles, with most programs administered by the Administration on Aging (AOA) within the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS). Discretionary funding for OAA Titles II, III, IV, VI, and VII is provided in annual HHS appropriations, while Title V funding is provided in the annual DOL appropriations. Congress has reauthorized and amended the act multiple times, with the last reauthorization in 2006 authorizing appropriations through FY2011. The Older Americans Act (OAA) was last reauthorized in 2006, authorizing appropriations through FY2011. Despite the expiration of authorizations, Congress has continued to fund OAA programs. This report discusses OAA funding, including an overview of FY2015 funding, a breakdown of current-year funding for programs, funding history since FY2001, and legislative activity for FY2015 appropriations. The report provides an overview of OAA's FY2015 funding, including a detailed breakdown of current-year funding for programs and activities. It also reviews OAA's funding history since FY2001, summarizes FY2015 legislative activity for appropriations, and discusses funding decisions for selected OAA programs. Appendixes offer more detailed funding information and history. The FY2015 Consolidated and Further Continuing Appropriations Act (P.L. 113-235) funded OAA programs at $1.878 billion, which is $6.5 million (0.3%) more than FY2014 funding. The FY2015 Consolidated and Further Continuing Appropriations Act (P.L. 113-235) allocated $1.878 billion for Older Americans Act (OAA) programs, a slight increase from FY2014. Title III programs received the majority of funding (70.7%), focusing on nutrition, supportive services, family caregivers, and health promotion. Title V, the CSEOA Program, received 23.1% of the funding, while the remaining funds were allocated to AOA-administered activities under Title II (2.7%). Approximately 130,000 Holocaust survivors are estimated to be beneficiaries of the program. The President's FY2015 budget proposed $5.0 million in OAA Title IV funding to establish a Holocaust Survivor Assistance Fund, which would provide supportive services for Holocaust survivors living in poverty. The Fund would also receive matching dollars from private philanthropy for services like legal assistance and case management. The Senate bill did not propose funding for the Holocaust Survivor program. The Senate bill and H.R. 5464 did not specify funding for the Holocaust Survivor Assistance Fund due to budget constraints. However, FY2015 final funding included $2.5 million in new discretionary funding to provide supportive services for aging Holocaust survivors. The FY2015 final funding did not establish the proposed Holocaust Survivor Assistance Fund in H.R. 5464, but it included $2.5 million in new discretionary funding for supportive services for aging Holocaust survivors. Aging and Disability Resource Centers (ADRCs) aim to provide a single entry point for information on long-term services and supports, including counseling, access to public programs, discharge planning, and care transition services. Aging and Disability Resource Centers (ADRCs) offer counseling on long-term services and supports, access to public programs like Medicaid, and discharge planning services to help individuals stay in their homes after hospitalization. There are over 500 ADRC sites nationwide, with 5.2 million client contacts in FY2012. ADRCs received $10 million in funding from FY2010 to FY2014 under the ACA. ADRCs operate in 50 states, two territories, and the District of Columbia, with 5.2 million client contacts in FY2012. They received $10 million in mandatory funding from FY2010 to FY2014 under the ACA. The President's FY2015 budget proposed no discretionary funding for ADRCs but suggested $20.0 million each year for five years in renewed mandatory funding. The budget justification highlighted the history of funding for ADRCs, with $100 million provided since 2003 to develop infrastructure. The Senate bill proposed $6.1 million in discretionary funding for ADRCs and urged ACL to improve coordination among ADRCs, AAAs, and CILs. The Senate bill proposed $6.1 million in discretionary funding for ADRCs under the Medicaid Balancing Incentive Payments Program, urging improved coordination among ADRCs, AAAs, and CILs for consumer access to long-term services and supports. Final FY2015-enacted funding also provided $6.1 million to ADRCs, not meeting the President's budget request for additional mandatory funding. The FY2015-enacted funding for ADRCs remained at $6.1 million in discretionary funding, failing to meet the President's request for additional mandatory funding. The White House Conferences on Aging have historically addressed concerns of older individuals and guided federal policymakers, with the first conference held in 1961. The National Conference on Aging in 1950 was the precursor to the White House Conferences on Aging, which have been held in every decade since 1961. The President's FY2015 budget proposed funding for a conference in 2015, but the Senate bill did not allocate dedicated funding, suggesting support from existing resources. The House Conference on Aging in 2015 did not receive dedicated funding from the Senate bill due to budget constraints. H.R. 5464 and final FY2015 appropriations also did not specify funding for the White House Conference on Aging. The White House plans to hold the conference in 2015 in Washington, DC, but without direct appropriations, the scale and scope of the conference will be different from previous ones. The White House plans to hold the 2015 Conference on Aging in Washington, DC. The conference will utilize technology to engage more people and will focus on key policy areas such as retirement security, healthy aging, long-term services, and elder justice.
